breaking_news.title: Apple Fixes Zero-Day Exploited in 'Extremely Sophisticated' Attacks
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Apple has released emergency security updates to patch a zero-day vulnerability that was actively exploited in highly targeted attacks. The flaw, though not yet publicly disclosed with full technical details, was leveraged by threat actors to compromise specific high-value individuals. Apple described the attacks as "extremely sophisticated," indicating nation-state or highly resourced actor involvement.

Paragraph 2: While the exact attack vector and affected devices remain undisclosed, the severity and targeted nature suggest the vulnerability likely enabled full device compromise, including data exfiltration, surveillance, and remote code execution. This incident underscores the growing use of zero-days in precision espionage operations against journalists, activists, and government officials.

breaking_news.title: Microsoft Notepad RCE Flaw Abused via Markdown Links
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Microsoft patched CVE-2026-21223, a remote code execution vulnerability in Windows 11 Notepad that leveraged its new Markdown support. Attackers could craft malicious Markdown files containing links that, when clicked, silently executed local or remote binaries without triggering Windows security warnings like SmartScreen or UAC prompts. The flaw stemmed from improper handling of Markdown link parsing in Notepad.

Paragraph 2: This vulnerability enables silent malware delivery with minimal user interaction, bypassing multiple layers of defense. Given Notepad’s ubiquitous use across enterprises and government agencies, the attack surface is massive. The flaw was actively exploited in the wild before patching, making it a high-priority remediation for defenders.

breaking_news.title: Microsoft Outlook Add-in Hijacked in Supply Chain Attack
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A malicious actor hijacked the legitimate AgreeTo Outlook add-in—distributed via the Microsoft Store—and repurposed it as a phishing kit. The attacker compromised the add-in’s domain and redirected users to a fake Microsoft login page, harvesting over 4,000 Microsoft account credentials. This represents a rare supply chain compromise of a Microsoft Store application, exploiting trust in official distribution channels.

Paragraph 2: The breach impacts all users of the AgreeTo add-in, spanning enterprises, financial institutions, and government agencies. The incident demonstrates how attackers are increasingly weaponizing trusted software ecosystems to bypass user skepticism and security controls like MFA prompts, significantly elevating phishing success rates.

breaking_news.title: Conduent Data Breach Impacts 25 Million People
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Business services provider Conduent disclosed a massive data breach affecting at least 25 million individuals—far exceeding earlier estimates of 10 million. The breach, originating from a January 2025 cyberattack, exposed highly sensitive PII including Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, health records, and insurance information. Volvo Group North America confirmed nearly 17,000 employees were impacted, with Texas and Oregon seeing 15 million and 10 million affected respectively.

Paragraph 2: As a major third-party vendor to government and healthcare entities, the breach represents a textbook supply chain compromise with cascading impact. The scale and sensitivity of exposed data significantly increase risks of identity theft, insurance fraud, and targeted social engineering. Regulators and affected individuals are likely to pursue legal action, potentially triggering major compliance penalties under GDPR, HIPAA, and state laws.

breaking_news.title: APT36 and SideCopy Target Indian Defense with Cross-Platform RATs
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Pakistan-linked APT36 (also tracked as Transparent Tribe), in coordination with the SideCopy infrastructure, launched a multi-pronged campaign targeting Indian defense and government-aligned organizations. The attackers deployed cross-platform remote access trojans—including Geta RAT, Ares RAT, and DeskRAT—on both Windows and Linux systems to steal sensitive data and maintain persistent access. Campaigns leveraged spear-phishing emails and compromised credentials as initial access vectors.

Paragraph 2: The targeting of military and government entities suggests strategic intelligence gathering, potentially aimed at compromising defense plans, personnel data, and classified communications. The use of Linux-targeting malware indicates preparation for infrastructure compromise beyond Windows desktops, including servers and network devices critical to national defense operations.

breaking_news.title: UNC1069 Uses AI Lures to Target Crypto Organizations
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: North Korea-linked APT UNC1069 has intensified operations targeting cryptocurrency firms using AI-generated content and social engineering. The group compromised Telegram accounts, scheduled fake Zoom meetings, and deployed the ClickFix infection vector to deliver malware on Windows and macOS systems. AI-generated video and voice cloning were reportedly used to impersonate executives and technical staff during targeted social engineering engagements.

Paragraph 2: This campaign reflects a dangerous evolution in APT tradecraft—integrating generative AI to enhance deception and bypass human and technical defenses. The focus on crypto organizations suggests financial theft as the primary objective, with stolen credentials and malware enabling wallet theft, exchange account takeovers, and insider data exfiltration.

breaking_news.title: Microsoft February Patch Tuesday Fixes Six Actively Exploited Zero-Days
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Microsoft’s February 2026 Patch Tuesday addressed 59 vulnerabilities, including six actively exploited zero-days—three publicly known. Critical flaws include CVE-2026-21510 (Windows Shell SmartScreen bypass), CVE-2026-21513 (MSHTML security bypass), and CVE-2026-21533 (Remote Desktop Services EoP). These flaws enable privilege escalation, code execution, and security feature bypass with minimal user interaction.

Paragraph 2: CISA added five of the six flaws to its KEV catalog, underscoring active exploitation in the wild. The combination of shell and MSHTML bypasses allows attackers to silently execute payloads after social engineering, dramatically lowering the barrier to successful compromise. Organizations with delayed patching cycles face elevated risk of ransomware and espionage intrusions.

breaking_news.title: Reynolds Ransomware Uses BYOVD to Disable EDR Before Encryption
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A newly discovered ransomware family named Reynolds embeds a Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD) technique directly into its payload to disable endpoint security tools before encryption. Researchers identified the use of the vulnerable NsecSoft driver to escalate privileges and disable EDR agents—bypassing traditional detection mechanisms. Initially misattributed to Black Basta, further analysis confirmed Reynolds as a distinct, emerging threat.

Paragraph 2: The integration of BYOVD into the ransomware itself—rather than deploying a separate tool—makes the attack more stealthy and efficient. This technique allows Reynolds to operate undetected in environments with robust security controls, increasing the likelihood of successful encryption and data theft. The emergence of this novel delivery method signals a new phase in ransomware evolution focused on defense evasion.
